I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) responds to South Asian 
developing member countries’ (DMC) needs in the urban sector as articulated in the country 
partnership strategies (CPS). The CPS’ have a  strong emphasis on knowledge management 
and  solutions,  results  orientation,  and  regional  cooperation.  The  TA  also  recognizes  that 
solutions for increasingly complex urban environments require bold action guided by knowledge. 
 
2.  The draft concept paper, including the design and monitoring framework, and financing 
and implementation arrangements were shared and discussed with the four governments.1 
They expressed interest in participating in the K-Hub; and agreed with the TA impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements and indicative terms of 
reference. ADB asked each government to nominate a national center to lead hub activities in 
their country; and the government of India agreed to host the regional center.2 
 
3.  The  TA  aligns  with  ADB’s  commitment  to  foster  development  knowledge.  This 
commitment aims to enhance the capacity of DMCs and improve the quality of ADB operations. 
ADB’s Strategy 2020 recognizes that supporting DMCs to gain knowledge is an important driver 
of change.3 The TA therefore aims to strengthen the capacity of urban research and training 
institutions in South Asia and develop a regional network for creating and sharing urban sector 
knowledge. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The TA aims to build the capacity of existing urban research or training institutions in 
select countries in South Asia to provide policy makers and practitioners with innovative and 
evidence-based solutions. This objective is increasingly relevant since urbanization is generally 
on an upward trajectory5 throughout the region and investments have failed to keep pace with 
this growth.  Many  of  the  region’s  cities  are facing  similar challenges of  inadequate  urban 
infrastructure,  environmental  degradation,  and lack  of (or  low-quality) services.  South  Asia 
accounts for almost half of the world’s urban poor. Maintaining vital economic growth while 
ensuring and improving access to services and a livable environment, including for the poor, is a 
major challenge facing cities in South Asia and will be the focus of the K-Hub. 
 
5.  Challenges  and  opportunities.  The  challenges  to  enhancing  city  competitiveness, 
inclusiveness,  and  environmental  sustainability  include  poor  leadership,  weak  governance, 
operating inefficiencies, need for substantial capital investments, and a lack of baseline data for 
effective analysis. Strategic thinking is needed on how to grapple with these issues and develop 
more integrated and evidence-based solutions to be implemented at scale. While South Asia 
has good examples to learn from, national and regional knowledge remains fragmented. The K-
Hub will help to consolidate existing and future knowledge and disseminate it widely. It will also

be a catalyst to accelerate the analysis of successes and failures, extract lessons from urban 
interventions, develop evidence-based solutions, and lead the debate on critical urban issues 
across the region. It will also provide a platform for engaging with organizations outside the 
South Asia region, including universities, think tanks, and other knowledge hubs. 
 
6.   The TA supports ADB’s Urban Operational Plan, 2012–2020 and its objective of an 
integrated approach to urban development with systematic benefits and improvements in the 
quality of life in Asia’s cities. ADB will leverage the K-Hub to (i) develop and promote innovative 
and cross-cutting ideas, (ii) integrate learning into ADB investment projects and advisory work, 
and (iii) strengthen knowledge partnerships in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be improved urban policy formulation and service delivery in selected 
South  Asian  DMCs.  The  outcome  is  improved  capacity  for  knowledge  generation  and 
management in the urban sector in selected South Asian DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will (i) develop sector and thematic knowledge products, (ii) produce technical 
and policy briefs, (iii) build capacity of national centers to strengthen evidence-based policy 
advocacy, (iv) disseminate knowledge, (v) formulate recommendations to improve university 
urban planning curricula, (vi) develop twinning arrangements between municipalities and service 
providers, and (vii) conduct regional and country learning events and networking opportunities. 
The TA will build capacity for the K-Hub’s sustainable operations. The TA has four outputs. 
 
9.  Output 1: Regional knowledge hub established. The TA will operationalize the hub, 
consolidate  and  share  knowledge,  and  develop  a  network  between  national  centers  and 
strengthen links with policy makers and practitioners. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Improved  capacity  for  outcome-oriented  research  and  knowledge 
dissemination. The TA will assess current capacity of national centers for evidence-based 
policy advocacy; and build the capacity of researchers and trainers for more outcome-oriented 
approaches to use knowledge to inform policy and practice. It will provide national centers with 
opportunities to apply these skills through (i) original research that is operationally relevant to 
governments and ADB (three knowledge products),6 (ii) the development of technical and policy 
briefs, and (iii) the provision of design and implementation support for twinning arrangements. 
The working group will decide on the research agenda (i.e., exact topics to be studied) based on 
demand, identified gaps, relevance to South Asia and operations, and competitive advantage of 
the  national  centers.  Learning  activities  will  include  structured  twinning  arrangements  for 
municipalities and service providers and a forum for mayors. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Improved  urban  management  and  planning  education  curriculum 
prepared. The TA will review current urban planning curricula in the region, and identify gaps 
and opportunities for strengthening it, including consultations and discussions, expert analysis, 
and survey of graduates to understand the skills gap.  
 
                                                
6  The knowledge products may have different styles and objectives. For example, they may include documentation 
and analysis of successful experiences, or provide “how to” guidance in the form of a manual.

3 
12.  Output 4: Improved capacity for managing knowledge hub operations. The TA 
focus  will  be  on  ensuring  effective  management  of  hub  operations  and  thinking  ahead  to 
sustainability.  All  of  the  national  centers  are  existing  institutions  with  ongoing  programs, 
activities, and funding arrangements. The TA complements and strengthens these existing 
activities and competencies, adds a regional dimension, and strengthens their national role. The 
business  model  for  the  K-Hub  will  be  elaborated  at  an  early  stage  of  implementation  in 
consultation with governments, and a consultant will work with each national center to develop a 
business plan related to innovative sanitation activities.7 
 
13.  Emphasis on innovative sanitation. The specific topics for research, learning events, 
and twinning partnerships will be determined during implementation. Prospective topics include 
(i) public–private partnerships (PPPs) for nonrevenue water reduction and 24-hour, 7-days a 
week supply; (ii) improving the implementation of wastewater contracts; (iii) corporatization of 
utilities; (iv) municipal finance; (v) metropolitan and regional planning and governance; (vi) low-
carbon  urban  development;  (vii)  multimodal  transport  systems;  and  (viii)  urban  flood 
management.  Innovative  sanitation  will  be  strongly  emphasized.  Sanitation  is  a  challenge 
affecting all cities in South Asia, with dire consequences for public health, the environment, and 
the economy. In response, with the support of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the K-Hub 
will lead research, learning events, and twinning partnerships on non-network urban sanitation 
solutions at scale, with a focus on PPPs, business models, and affordable technology. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.35 million, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Sanitation  Financing  Partnership  Trust  Fund 8 under  the  Water  Financing 
Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The remaining $850,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V and TASF-others).9 The cost 
estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB is the executing agency and will play a leading role in quality assurance. ADB will 
support national centers in research design, analysis, and marketing of findings. It will monitor 
implementation progress through regular contact with the regional and national centers and as a 
member of the working group. 
 
16.   The implementing agencies in each participating country are:  
(i)  Bangladesh: Local Government Division of the Ministry of Local Government,   
Rural Development and Cooperatives;  
(ii)  India: Ministry of Urban Development;  
(iii)  Nepal: Ministry of Urban Development; and   
(iv)  Sri Lanka: Urban Development Authority.  
 
17.  The role of the implementing agencies is to (i) support and endorse their respective 
center  as  the  national  hub  for  urban  knowledge  management,  (ii)  promote  integration  of 
knowledge with policy and operations, (iii) provide guidance to national centers on research 
topics and hub activities, (iv) provide opportunities for national centers to share findings with

policy  makers  and  practitioners,  and  (v)  provide  leadership  on  the  K-Hub  sustainability 
framework. 
 
18.   Regional and national centers. The K-Hub headquarters will be in India at the National 
Institute  of  Urban  Affairs  (NIUA).  Each  participating  country  government  has  selected  a 
government-endorsed  national  center  for  urban  knowledge  management  based  on  their 
capacity, reputation for urban sector research and training, and comparative advantage. The 
national centers for each country are (i) Bangladesh: the International Training Network (ITN) 
Centre at Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology (BUET); (ii) India: NIUA (both 
regional and national center); (iii) Nepal: Urban Development Training Centre; and (iv) Sri Lanka: 
University of Moratuwa, Department of Town and Country Planning (see Figure 1). 
 
19.  Working group. The TA will be guided by a working group chaired by a representative 
of the regional center who will act as coordinator. The group will include a member of each 
national center and ADB. It will adopt a charter to guide its operations and meet at least 
annually or as needed for planning and to monitor progress of TA activities.10 It will prepare joint 
outputs, including a business plan and a sustainability plan. The implementing agencies will be 
invited to participate in the first meeting and other meetings as appropriate. 
 
20.  Procurement. The TA will be implemented from January 2014 to December 2016 with 
an additional 3 months for closing. It requires approximately 156.5 person-months of consulting 
services (4.5 person-months of international inputs and 152 person-months of national inputs). 
Outline  terms  of  reference  are  in  Appendix  3  and  detailed  terms  of  reference  are  in 
Supplementary  Appendix  B.  National  and  international  individual  consultants  and  national 
centers will be selected following ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time). For Bangladesh, single source selection (SSS)11 to recruit ITN-BUET as a 
national center is justified as it is the leading university and research institute for urban planning 
and the water and sanitation sector, and has the multidisciplinary staff required for successful 
implementation. For India, SSS to recruit NIUA as the regional and national center is justified 
because of its government-endorsed mandate (urban sector, national scope, bridging the gap 
between researchers and practitioners) and wide network and track record working  at the 
central, state, and local levels.12 For Sri Lanka, SSS to recruit the University of Moratuwa as the 
national center is justified because it is the only university in the country with an urban planning 
department, and the country has no urban sector think tanks. For Nepal, SSS to recruit the 
Urban Development Training Centre is justified because of its mandate (urban sector, national 
scope) and strong networks with municipalities across the country. In addition, all four national 
centers  have  been  endorsed  by  their  governments  as  critical  to  the  implementation  and 
sustainability of the K-Hub initiative. The contracts of national centers will be output-based 
according  to  an  agreed  business  plan.  Disbursements  and  procurement  will  be  made  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time) and Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). 13

mediums, including ADB and national center channels and networks. The outputs will be in a 
variety of forms, including publications, policy notes, reports, conference proceedings, and the

22.   Monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  ADB  project  team  will  work  closely  with  national 
centers to develop the detailed business plan in accordance with the design and monitoring 
framework,  and  regularly  monitor  implementation  progress.  National  centers  will  prepare 
quarterly progress reports. The regional center will submit a consolidated quarterly report within 
30  days  of  quarter  end  to  ADB  and  the  implementing  agencies.  ADB  will  consult  with 
participating governments in preparing the TA completion report, which evaluates the quality of 
the outputs post-implementation.
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Sanitation Financing Partnership Trust Fund under the Water 
Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent 
 
of $850,000 on a grant basis for the South Asia Urban Knowledge Hub, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
 
                                                
14 Other countries in South Asia, e.g. Bhutan and Maldives, will not be excluded from participation in the K-Hub. They 
will be invited to participate in events and may be invited for full membership in the future.

A.  Regional and India National Center 
 
1.   The National Institute of Urban Affairs (NIUA) in India will play the roles of regional and 
national  centers.  Its  regional  responsibilities  include  coordinating  the  national  centers; 
developing  linkages  between  knowledge  hubs,  professional  associations,  and  universities 
outside the region; leading regional activities and building the profile of the South Asia Urban 
Knowledge Hub (‘K-Hub’); developing knowledge tools (e.g., website); and producing regional 
knowledge products. Its national responsibilities include identifying innovative practices in the 
urban sector, coordinating between relevant partners in India, developing India-specific policy 
and technical notes, and supporting a twinning arrangement.

working on urban knowledge management in South Asia;  
  (ii)  an urban specialist (10 person-months) with a master’s degree or higher, at least 
10 years of professional experience, at least 5 years experience working on 
urban development in South Asia, and research experience preferred;

(iii)  an infrastructure specialist (10 person months) with a master’s degree or higher 
in  economics,  engineering,  or  other  relevant  degree;  at  least  10  years 
professional  experience;  at  least  5  years  experience  working  on  urban 
infrastructure in South Asia; and research experience preferred; and 
(iv)   other experts (to be determined) may be needed for an estimated 10 person-
months. 
 
B.  Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka National Centers  
 
3.  The responsibilities of the national centers in Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka include 
identifying innovative practices, coordinating between relevant partners in-country, developing 
country-specific policy and technical notes, supporting a twinning arrangement, and developing 
a sustainability plan post-ADB financial and technical support.

4.  The following detailed tasks will be conducted: 
(i)  participate in regional hub planning activities; 
(ii)  provide inputs into the development of three regional knowledge products; 
(iii)  participate in the review process of university urban planning curricula; 
(iv)  organize national and subnational seminars and learning events; 
(v)  establish an annual eminent speaker lecture series; 
(vi)  develop at least two case studies or technical briefs, and two policy briefs; 
(vii)  participate in training to improve evidence-based policy advocacy; and 
(viii)  identify and support twinning arrangement for sanitation. 
 
5.   Qualifications (national consultants). The assignment is for an estimated 33 person-
months per national center including the inputs of the following:
 
 
(i)   a project coordinator (10 person-months) with a master’s degree or higher, at 
least 15 years of professional experience, demonstrated experience working on 
urban knowledge management in South Asia;

(ii)  an urban specialist (10 person-months) with a master’s degree or higher, at least 
10 years of professional experience, at least 5 years experience working on 
urban development in South Asia, and research experience preferred; 
(iii)   an infrastructure specialist (5 person-months) with a master’s degree or higher in 
economics, engineering, or other relevant field; at least 10 years of professional 
experience; at least 5 years experience working on urban infrastructure in South 
Asia; and research experience preferred; and 
(iv)  other experts as needed (8 person-months). 
 
C.  Knowledge Management Specialist (international) 
 
6.  The assignment involves supporting four national centers (Bangladesh, India, Nepal, 
and Sri Lanka) to improve their skills in outcome-oriented research and build their capacity to 
influence policy makers and practitioners through evidence-based policy advocacy. The work 
will mainly be carried out remotely, with one regional workshop. 
 
7.  The consultant will carry out the following tasks (estimated 3 person-months): 
(i)  Assessment.  Assess  the  current  capacity  of  the  four  national  centers  for 
outcome-oriented  research  through  survey  (designed  by  consultant)  and 
telephone interview, and assess the effectiveness of links between the national 
center and policy makers. 
(ii)  National center strategies. Develop a template that national centers may use to 
develop their own strategy for strengthening the links between themselves and 
policy makers, and review the strategies and provide comments once they have 
been drafted by the national centers. 
(iii)  Regional workshop. Develop material and lead 2-day workshop in the region 
covering the following topics: results of assessment, outcome-oriented research, 
strengthening links between policy makers and researchers (why it’s important, 
how  to  do  it,  share  template  developed for strategy),  how  to  write  effective 
technical briefs, and how to write effective policy briefs. 
The consultant will use the results of the assessment to tailor the workshop 
activities. The consultant is expected to develop the draft program and may ask 
participants in advance to prepare presentations on certain topics. The workshop 
is meant to be interactive and use a variety of teaching styles (not only lecture). 
(iv)  Peer review. The consultant will review a total of eight policy and technical briefs 
produced by national centers and provide comments on how to improve their 
structure and presentation of key messages. The goal is to mentor  national 
centers  on  improving  their  evidence-based  policy  advocacy  through  written 
documents. The consultant will also review three knowledge products developed 
by  the  regional  knowledge  hub  and  provide  comments  on  improving  their 
marketability and/or packaging of messages for policy makers and practitioners. 
 
8.   Qualifications. The specialist must have a master’s degree or higher, at least 10 years 
of professional experience, demonstrated experience working on knowledge management in 
developing  countries,  and  demonstrated  experience  building  capacity  for  outcome-oriented 
research and evidence-based policy advocacy.

12    Appendix 3 
D.  Urban Specialist (international) 
 
9.  The urban specialist will help design and facilitate a South Asia forum for mayors to be 
hosted  by  ADB  in  Manila  in  Q2  2014.  The  forum  will  include  participants  from  about  
10 secondary cities in South Asia. The objective will be to engage with mayors on pressing 
issues related to urban development, share experiences, and strengthen ADB’s partnership with 
these cities and their leaders. 
 
10.  The assignment is for an estimated 1.5 person-months. The specialist will (i) work with 
ADB to finalize the forum program and develop the detailed program; (ii) be responsible for 
securing presentations and/or preparing the presentations and activities; and (iii) facilitate the 
event, manage the national consultant and assistant, and work closely with the ADB  task 
manager throughout the assignment. 
 
11.  The expected deliverables and due dates are (i) detailed program for the program due 
by  Q1  2014  (payment  25%)  and  (ii)  facilitation  of  the  forum  and  final  report  (summary 
proceedings including presentations) by Q2 2014 (payment 75%). 
 
12.   Qualifications. The urban specialist must have a master’s degree or higher; at least  
10 years of professional experience in the urban sector, particularly in municipal management 
issues; experience in organizing international forum is preferred; and demonstrated experience 
working on knowledge management in developing countries and organizing learning events. 
 
E.  Urban Specialist (national) 
 
13.  The urban specialist will support the international consultant to organize and facilitate a 
South Asia forum for mayors to be hosted by ADB in Manila.  
 
14.  The assignment is for an estimated 4 person-months paid on a lump sum basis. The 
urban specialist will work closely with the international consultant and provide support with 
logistics and planning, and:  
(i)  manage logistics related to the forum (e.g., invitations, flights, accommodation, 
venue, meals, printing); 
(ii)  support communications with invitees on any issues related to the forum; and 
(iii)  provide any other support, as requested, by the international consultant. 
 
15.   Qualifications. The urban specialist (Philippine national) must have a master’s degree 
or higher; at least 10 years of professional experience in the urban sector; and experience in 
organizing international forums is preferred.
